page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: There have been settlements in the survey block since prehistoric times. Traces of a{prehistoric hill-fort and {field system}have been found at Arbury Banks, about 1 Km. south-west of Ashwell centre. There are ring ditches and enclosures at Slip End, about 2Km. east of the village. In the middle ages Ashwell was an {important market town.}Remains of this can be seen in the large 14 Century Church and the half-timbered Tudor building which now houses the Museum. Other buildings of historical significance include the 14 Century Foresters' Cottages; 15 Century Bear House; the 16 Century St. John's Guildhouse, Dixie's Farm and Duck Lake Farm;the 19 Century Rectory and the Tudor Chantry House. All these give a period flavour to Ashwell (see also page 19)
